title: 107_s1058
content: The Act may be cited as the "Biodiesel Renewable Fuels Act" and includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding a credit for biodiesel used as fuel. The "Biodiesel Renewable Fuels Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a biodiesel fuels credit based on the biodiesel mixture credit, which is calculated by multiplying the biodiesel mixture rate by the number of gallons of qualified biodiesel mixture blends. The biodiesel mixture rate varies for different blends, with 3.0 cents for a B-2 blend and 20.0 cents for a B-20 blend. The terms B-1 blend, B-2 blend, and B-20 blend are defined based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture. The terms B-1 blend, B-2 blend, and B-20 blend are defined based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture, with specific criteria for each blend. The applicable amount for a B-1 blend is determined by multiplying 1.5 cents by the percentage of biodiesel in the blend. The term 'applicable amount' in this context refers to the calculation for a B-1 blend, which is 1.5 cents multiplied by the percentage of biodiesel in the blend divided by 1 percent. A 'qualified biodiesel mixture' is a blend of diesel and biodiesel sold or used by the taxpayer in their trade or business. The taxpayer can claim a credit for biodiesel used in a qualified biodiesel mixture sold or used as fuel in their trade or business. Casual off-farm production is not eligible for this credit. The taxpayer can claim a credit for biodiesel used in a qualified biodiesel mixture sold or used as fuel in their trade or business. No credit is allowed for casual off-farm production of a qualified biodiesel mixture. The amount of the credit may be reduced to account for any benefit provided by the exemption from excise tax. Definitions and special rules apply for the purposes of this section. The term 'biodiesel' is defined as monoalkyl esters of long chain fatty acids derived from vegetable oils for use in diesel engines. It includes esters from various vegetable oils. Registration requirements apply to biodiesel meeting specific criteria. The term 'biodiesel' includes esters derived from various vegetable oils and must meet EPA registration requirements under the Clean Air Act. Imposition of tax on persons who separate biodiesel from qualified biodiesel mixture or use the mixture other than as fuel, based on biodiesel mixture rate and gallons used. Applicable laws apply. Tax is imposed on individuals who separate biodiesel from a qualified mixture or use it for non-fuel purposes. The tax amount is calculated based on the biodiesel mixture rate and the number of gallons used. Applicable laws, including penalties, apply to this tax. Additionally, estates and trusts are subject to pass-through rules similar to those in section 52. Taxpayers have the option to elect not to apply the biodiesel fuels credit. Taxpayers can elect not to apply the biodiesel fuels credit for any taxable year by following regulations prescribed by the Secretary. The election must be made within the 3-year period from the last date for filing the return for that taxable year. The election must be made within the 3-year period from the last date for filing the return for that taxable year. The biodiesel fuels credit is treated as part of the general business credit under Section 38(b). No carryback of the biodiesel fuels credit is allowed before January 1, 2003. The biodiesel fuels credit can be elected not to be applied for any taxable year within a 3-year period from the last date for filing the return. It is part of the general business credit under Section 38(b) and cannot be carried back before January 1, 2003. Amendments have been made to sections 39(d) and 196(c) to reflect this. Amendments to Section 196(c) include adding a new paragraph (11) for the biodiesel fuels credit under section 40A. The table of sections is also updated to include this new item after section 40. The amendments made by section 40A apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The excise taxes on biodiesel mixtures are reduced under section 3. The amendment to Section 4081 introduces a new subsection (f) regarding biodiesel mixtures. It states that the tax rate for qualified biodiesel mixtures will be reduced by the biodiesel mixture rate. Additionally, the tax rate for diesel fuel used in producing a qualified biodiesel mixture will also be reduced. The tax rate for diesel fuel used in producing a qualified biodiesel mixture is reduced by the biodiesel mixture rate, calculated based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture. The tax rate for diesel fuel used in producing a qualified biodiesel mixture is reduced by the biodiesel mixture rate, calculated based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture. Definitions and rules from section 40A apply to this subsection. Conforming amendments are made to section 4041 for the sale or use of qualified biodiesel mixtures. The tax rate for diesel fuel used in producing a qualified biodiesel mixture is reduced by the biodiesel mixture rate as defined in section 40A. Conforming amendments are made to sections 4041 and 6427 for the sale or use of qualified biodiesel mixtures. The amendments made by this section, effective January 1, 2002, allow for the payment of the biodiesel mixture rate to individuals using diesel fuel in producing qualified biodiesel mixtures. SEC. 4. HIGHWAY TRUST FUND HELD HARMLESS. Transfers from Commodity Credit Corporation funds will offset reductions in Highway Trust Fund receipts due to amendments made by this Act, based on Treasury Secretary estimates. Adjustments will be made for any estimation errors.
